awd_abstract_narration:
Certified welders with advanced science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) knowledge and skills are vital to the United States petroleum, food production and processing, transportation, and manufacturing industries, and this project includes industry partners from these sectors. Because of this great need, the Welding Distance Community Outreach (WELDCO) program at West Hills Community College is designed to meet the needs for a growing sector of advanced welding technicians on the West Side of the California impoverished Central Valley. The program seeks to transport and make mobile a successful, face-to-face, welding program and offer it in geographically isolated areas within the service area of the college where career and technical education (CTE) has been historically very limited. Cultural changes will occur within the regional community as children of first-generation immigrants attain post-secondary education and gainful employment, thus creating a positive generational learning outcome. Further benefits will accrue to the region as adult learners, those already employed seeking to improve job skills, and the unemployed capitalize on the accessibility of this education program. The project will impact both the state and the nation as this education paradigm is shared with other community colleges and organizations for improving employer partnerships and growth. A robust project evaluation will study the impact of this project on business and industry and on the students and workers involved. 

WELDCO is a cohort-specific curriculum design which includes variable integration of e-learning, Virtual Reality (VR) welding technology, and traditional training as a means of engaging nontraditional students. Formative and summative assessments will be employed to assess curriculum performance and modifications needed. The package takes full advantage of California legislative mandates and state funding for education programs (including high school pathways and post-secondary education) to enhance the impact on education and subsequent employment in the region. Students will benefit from the expanded internship opportunities and employer collaborations to help create a regional impact. This project focuses on 3 objectives: (a) development of a blended welding curriculum  to integrate e-learning, VR instruction, and traditional classroom instruction that will lead to American Welding Society (AWS) certification; (b) optimization of course delivery to maximize efficiency, effectiveness, and engagement by addressing student cognitive preferences and learning styles; and (c) implementation of population specific recruitment to include Hispanic, minority, and female students.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: West Hills Community College North District Center

por.por_cntn:
WELDCO developed an online welding curriculum that blends distance learning, mobile lab, and welding simulator to enable diverse individuals in disadvantaged communities to acquire skills in welding. The purpose of this blended e-learning approach was to maximize education effectiveness by addressing differences in student learning styles at remote sites. By working in a disadvantaged community, we hope to implement population-specific recruitment, retention, and completion strategies to ensure a diversified workforce.

 

The gas, oil, processing, and agriculture industries in the Central Valley have a great need for welders. West Hills College Coalinga is the only college in the western San Joaquin Valley that offers welding specific to the region including multi-positional and pipe welding. These are advanced skills which make finding an instructor difficult because they are valuable in the field.

 

The blended distance education approach provides a model by which advanced welding technical skills can be taught from a home college location by an experienced instructor to a remote site with support from an instructional aide and online access to the experienced instructor. The instructional aide would not need the education or experience qualifications and thus would be easier to find and employ.

 

Welding instructor Chris Chaney used industry based NCCER materials to develop the content of all WHCC welding classes within the Canvas learning management system. These Canvas shells became the standard shells used by current welding classes and thus were incorporated into the local coursework.

 

Chris was also involved in the purchase of the initial VR Welding simulator. This simulator duplicated the welding process as viewed within a welding helmet while giving visual clues on a student’s technique. This simulator has the capability to provide a remote instructor with real time view of student welding technique for immediate feedback.

 

There were obstacles which required a change in approach within the grant. First, it was discovered that the available electrical power was not adequate for the requirements of the welding trailer. The approach changed to the collaborative use of a high school welding lab to hold the open enrolled classes instead of the trailer. The blended e-learning was used to teach two courses held at the Firebaugh High School welding lab.

 

It was also discovered that the band width and cellular network needed for the e-learning component was not adequate.  Students could not easily communicate with the main instructor because the lack of cell service and the design of the school’s IT network.  This also restricted the use of the simulator and the communications between the main instructor in Coalinga and the instructional aide in Firebaugh.

 

Though we had a lack of successful student completion within this blended learning project, our conclusion was that we learned of factors which can be corrected along with several other benefits. The problems and proposed solutions are documented in the Best Practices and Project Summary available from the PI.

 

COVID pandemic prevented the continued testing of the best practices, as schools limited access to buildings by external community members for safety of students. At the close of the project the blended learning was being used and tested at the West Hills College Coalinga welding lab.

 

The project did have other successes.  Beside determining best practices for offering blended learning courses, the project identified several recruitment strategies, concentrating on print media as opposed to social media due to broadband issues. The project also identified an instructor that speaks Spanish is better able to work with the many students from the community for which English is second language, for retention and successful completion.

 

 

 

This model could be applied to any discipline where there is specialized knowledge and skills as well as a shortage of qualified instructors, such as precision agriculture, irrigation, or integrated pest management.

 

This project may have the unintentional result of encouraging instructional aides to consider adjunct or full-time teaching careers.

 

This project expanded the vision for using simulators or educational kits in remote sites by instructional aides with limited technical knowledge to demonstrate field techniques in the classroom. We are working on an irrigation simulator that has actual field components on a tabletop and duplicates the field processes.

 

This project shows how to bring college courses to poor disadvantaged underrepresented communities. With limited personal or public transportation, reducing miles students needing technical training need to travel can make a difference.

 

We believe that WELDCO showed the potential for a blended learning approach. Advanced technical skills are very much needed in the Central Valley; having a structure in place where students can take a course to attain those skills, will help their families and economic health of the communities.

 

PI Terry Brase

(559)934-2701

terrybrase@whccd.edu

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2022
Modified by: Terry A Brase

The purpose of this blended e-learning approach was to maximize education effectiveness by addressing differences in student learning styles at remote sites. By working in a disadvantaged community, we hope to implement population-specific recruitment, retention, and completion strategies to ensure a diversified workforce.

West Hills College Coalinga is the only college in the western San Joaquin Valley that offers welding specific to the region including multi-positional and pipe welding. These are advanced skills which make finding an instructor difficult because they are valuable in the field.

The instructional aide would not need the education or experience qualifications and thus would be easier to find and employ.
